722314f-a.text:
Park Avenue, at N. E. corner of 68th Street, showina Punter College, (the old Normal College for Women), built about 1870. In the center of the Avenue, note the perk is being cut down on each
side.
Winter 1928-29.
Ewino Galloway, Photogrspher.

722313f-b.text:
Parl Sve ue, east side, north from E. 88th Street (extreme right), showing at that point a portion of old Hunter College (deolished in 1938), and to the north, the dual structure (white buildinn, peaked roof) that will be reconstructed for the Union Club for occupancy in August 1933. This building, bearin No'e. 705 Park Avenue and 101 E. 68th Street, is at the N.E. corner and is prominently depicted in View 2 in its new form. Also note in the latter instance the vacant 1ot where the old college stood. Exclusive of this and the club, the view remains the same.
September 11, 1931
View 2: April 25, 1938.
P.L. Sperr

722315f-a.text:
Park Avenue, east ide, north from East 68th to 69th Streets, showing the old Normal College for Women, erected about 1870. This is now a part of Hunter College and is under demolition (early 1938) Note, on the right of No. 1, The Thomas Hunter Hall on Lexington Avenue, and on the left of No. 2, the building at the N.F. corner of Park Avenue and 89th Street that became the home of the Union
Club in 1933.
TPe New York Tires of August 2, 1938, in an article on Page 21 announces the cerer onies to be held here on the construction of a new building that will cost ~6,414,OO0. of which the City's share ia ~3,527,700 and the P.W.A's ~2,886,300. CHarles H. Tuttle will preside and speeches will be made by the Mayor, Howard A. Gray, Coloiel M.E. Gilmore and Mrs. Walter S. Mack. This new structure will be 16 stories high and accommodate 5,000 students in 1O0 class rooms. Included also will be a library, cafeteria, auditorium,
gymnasium, swimming p001, theatre and laboratories.
Sent. 11, 1031.
Viet 2:June 12, 1937.

714232f-b.text:
East 68th Street, Aest from Lexington, to Park (left) Avenues, showing the southerly side of Thomas Hunter Hall (right) and the old lormal College for Women (now Hunter College). The latter, in 1938, is demolished, having been severly damaged by a fire in
1936.
The Nex York Times of Aug. 2, 1938, in an article on Page 21 announces the ceremonies to be held here on the construction of a ne1 building that will cost '6,414,00O. of which the City's share ~3,527,700 and the P.v.A's w2,886,300. Charles H. Tuttle will preside and speeches will be made by the layor, Howard A. Gray, Colonel k. E. Gilmore and Mrs. Valter S. Nack. This new structure will be 16 stories high and accommodate 5,0O0 students in 100 class rooms. Included also will be a library, auitorium,
gvmmnasium, swimming pool, theatre and luboratories.
For further views of this structure see, Park and Lexington
Avenues, and East 69th Street.

714233f-c.text:
East 68th Street, north side, east from Park, to Lexington Avenue, showing the old Hunter College Bldg. and the newer arnex. The former is now demolished (July 1938) and upon this site will rise a new and modern school plant. For further data see other
views in the files.
June 12, 1937
P. L. Sperr,
(223)
Two additional views of the same area at a later date showing the clearance on the westerly half of this block. To the extreme left are residential structures on the north side of East 69th Street.
April 25, 1938
Views 2 and 3
P. L. Sperr,

714234f-a.text:
The Baptist Home for the Aged, 116 East 68th Street, at and
adjoining the S.E. corner of Park Avenue.

1507997.title: Park Avenue - 68th Street - 69th Street, east side
1507997.folder: Park Avenue - 68th Street - 69th Street, east side, Manhattan, NY

722316f-a.text:
Park Avenue, east s ide, from o8th to o9th Streets, looking northeast up the southern slope of Lenox Hill. The view is acIOss the parks in the center of the avenue, showing the tower of the old Hunter Oollege buildings, which have occupied the block since about 1870. Beyond it, on the northeast corner of 69th Street is the white house that will be occupied by the Union Club ih 1933.
September 24, 1927.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.
